Description: Limestone sculpture fragment of quadruped depicted with fur, possibly a ram. Fur is painted red-brown. Badly worn head turns slightly to right. Something on back has broken off, but was not a rider. Short tail and legs are broken.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This figure of ram fits well with the cult of the major god revered in the Great Temenos, the ram-headed god Amun-Ra Baded (Yoyotte 1982/83; Guermeur 2005, 126-138). Small limestone figures of rams were rare at Naukartis (BM EA1886,0401.1483 and possibly Cambridge NA309). An unprovenanced parallel, has been dated to the Late period (Petrie Museum UC60056). Guermeur, I. 2005. Les cultes d’Amon hors-de-Thèbes, Turnhout. Yoyotte, J. 1982/83, ‘L’Amon de Naukratis’, Revue d’Égyptologie 34, 129–136.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.203) (Phase 3)
